title: The Bar has Always Been Moving. Are you?
summary: Technology adoption cycles are accelerating globally, with each innovation quickly becoming baseline expectationsâ€”fine-tuning models and proprietary AI are the next wave. Africa's historical lag in adopting new technologies compounds as an economic liability, requiring faster adoption strategies to remain competitive.
content:
Today's Wizardry Is Tomorrow's Bare Minimum


And Africa is running out of time to not care.
There is a story â€” the kind that gets passed around in African classrooms â€” about a colonial-era quack doctor who sold bottled cures to rural crowds.
His secret weapon wasn't the concoction. It was the label.
Printed paper. English words. A logo, if you could call it that.
The author who told this story noted, with quiet humor, that in that era, if you could print your claims, you were generally considered truthful. Literacy was new. The printed word carried the full weight of authority. The bottle didn't need to work. The label just needed to exist.
I think about that story every time I watch a new technology go from miracle to minimum.
Every generation has its wizardry. Every generation eventually forgets it was ever wizardry at all.
In the early 2000s across much of Africa, having an email address made you someone. Not just anyone â€” someone. A Yahoo address was a kind of credential. It said: I am connected to the world beyond this street.
By 2005, having a website meant you were serious. Businesses printed their URLs on flyers like they were printing certificates.
By 2010, a Facebook page could legitimize an entire company in the eyes of its customers.
By 2015, if your e-commerce store accepted card payments â€” genuinely processed a Visa transaction â€” you were operating at a level most of your competitors couldn't touch.
Each of these things, in its moment, was the difference between being taken seriously and being invisible.
Each of them is now table stakes.
This is not a uniquely African story, but it hits differently here â€” because the gap between when the world adopts something and when we adopt it has historically cost us. Every cycle we miss is compounding interest on a debt we didn't choose but keep paying.

title: How To Shut Up OpenClaw CLI Banner ğŸ¦
summary: OpenClaw CLI displays a decorative lobster banner on every invocation that can be suppressed by setting OPENCLAW_HIDE_BANNER in shell configuration. This environment variable eliminates banner overhead and improves output clarity during repeated CLI use.
content:
Every time you run an OpenClaw command, youâ€™re greeted with a little lobster and a â€œfunnyâ€ tagline:
ğŸ¦ OpenClaw 2026.2.15 (3fe22ea)
Gateway onlineâ€”please keep hands, feet, and appendages inside the shell at all times.

Cute the first time but by the hundredth invocation you start wondering if the lobster is mocking you personally. Moreover, it becomes hard to distinguish the outputs from your command with those vertical spaces.
I went down the plugin rabbit hole trying to suppress it â€” turns out the banner fires during CLI bootstrap, before the plugin system even loads. So no, you canâ€™t write a plugin to kill it. The lobster is faster than you.
But buried in the source code thereâ€™s a single env var doing the lordâ€™s work:
Add to your ~/.zshrc (or ~/.bashrc):
export OPENCLAW_HIDE_BANNER=1

Thatâ€™s it. One line. source ~/.zshrc and the lobster goes silent.
Youâ€™re welcome.

title: On AI and Other Drugs
summary: A backend engineer with 15 years of experience reflects on the AI adoption wave and initial skepticism before cautiously experimenting with Claude for logic design and debugging. The experience demonstrates how AI assistance can iterate on ideas effectively when used selectively.
content:
"Being a specialist is what I am, and maybe that is why I was so angry about the whole thing in the first place."
Hi, I hope your day is going well. This is my first post here (cross posted to my blog on Substack). Admittedly, I've had an account here years ago, but am now returning to writing as a healthy output and figured I should just make a new one.
I am a tech lead, "backend" engineer with about 7 years of experience in the industry. But I've been coding, and messing with tech for about 15 years now.
I am mostly self-taught, currently working as an advisor for a global high-end fashion brand. I truly like my job, the people are kind and reasonable. The work is occasionally quite interesting, no complaints. 
We've all been through an emotional rollercoaster to say the least, in the past few years with AI. Ever since the release of ChatGPT--until about 4 months later when 19 of it's best competitors came rushing to the market. And ever since, we have been chasing the next model, the next efficiency, the next marvel that will save us from the terrible burden of, well, doing things.
I mean you. You have probably been chasing the next model, the next release, the next automation. Me? I am very reluctant to write code with AI.
I've never had Copilot installed on my IDE (even when it was all the hype). I've never had an AI touch my code, not for personal projects and God forbid, never for production code. Until a few months ago, I did not even know what an "agent" was. By the way, who decided to call it that? It makes no sense. The naming conventions of AI related things go right above my head.
A few months ago, I "gave in" and took Claude for a test drive. Not Claude code, mind you, Claude.ai the chat bot. It helped me come up with the proper logic for some of my "low level" ideas. We've iterated multiple approaches, multiple versions of the code. We've solved bugs, (it was mostly me solving the bugs honestly, while he was chasing imaginary code monsters). 
Eventual
